form.preferredDefinition: The Exercise Dependence Scale is a 21-item self-administered scale that can be administered in individual and group settings and has been used with respondents 18 years and older. Participants indicate their responses to each of the 21 items in the blank space provided after each item. They indicate their responses on a Likert scale anchored at the extremes with never (1) and always (6). The Exercise Dependence Scale requires approximately 5 minutes to complete.

headerInstruction.text: Exercise Dependence Scale21. Instructions. Using the scale provided below, please complete the following questions as honestly as possible. The questions refer to current exercise beliefs and behaviors that have occurred in the past 3 months. ..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: I exercise to avoid feeling irritable. (exercise_avoid_feeling_irritable)
I exercise despite recurring physical problems. (exercise_despite_recurring_physical_problems)
I continually increase my exercise intensity to achieve the desired effects/benefits. (exercise_increase_intensity_forresults)
I am unable to reduce how long I exercise. (exercise_unableto_reduce_length)
I choose to exercise so that I can get out of spending time with family/friends. (exercise_insteadof_social_activity)
I spend a lot of time exercising. (exercise_time_spent)
I exercise longer than I intend. (exercise_longerthan_intended)
I exercise to avoid feeling anxious. (exercise_avoid_feeling_anxious)
I exercise when injured. (exercise_when_injured)
I continually increase my exercise frequency to achieve the desired effects/benefits. (exercise_increase_frequency_forresults)
I am unable to reduce how often I exercise. (exercise_unableto_reduce_frequency)
I think about exercise when I should be concentrating on school/work. (exercise_thoughts_insteadof_school_work)
I spend most of my free time exercising. (exercise_majorityof_free_time)
I exercise longer than I expect. (exercise_longerthan_expected)
I exercise to avoid feeling tense. (exercise_avoid_feeling_tense)
I exercise despite persistent physical problems. (exercise_despite_persistent_physical_problems)
I continually increase my exercise duration to achieve the desired effects/benefits. (exercise_increase_duration_forresults)
I am unable to reduce how intense I exercise. (exercise_unable_reduce_intensity)
A great deal of my time is spent exercising. (exercise_excusefrom_social_activity)
I exercise longer than I plan. (exercise_longerthan_planned)

Scoring: The proposed scoring procedure for the Exercise Dependence Scale is computer based, which allows for immediate and accurate scoring. The computer scoring of the Exercise Dependence Scale is based on the SPSS (Statistic Package for the Social Sciences). A syntax file (see https://www.phenxtoolkit.org/index.php?pageLink=browse.si.all) has been developed by the authors that enables immediate feedback to the Exercise Dependence Scale responses once the items are entered into SPSS. The syntax enables:1. Computing a total and subscale mean scores for Exercise Dependence Scale21. A higher score indicates more exercisedependent symptoms.2. Categorizing participants into either atrisk for exercise dependent, nondependentsymptomatic, or nondependentasymptomatic groups. The categorization into one of the three groups is generated by a scoring manual that consists of flowchart decision rules in which items or combinations or items determine if an individual would be classified in the dependent, symptomatic, or asymptomatic range on each of the 7 DSM IV criteria. Individuals who are classified into the dependent range on 3 or more of the DSM criteria are classified as exercise dependence. The dependent range is operationalized as indicating a score of 5 or 6 for that item. Individuals who scored in the 3 to 4 range are classified as symptomatic. These individuals may theoretically be considered atrisk for exercise dependence. Finally, individuals who score in the 12 range are classified as asymptomatic. (scoring_650201)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Exercise Dependence Scaleis a 21-item self-administered scale that can be administered in individual and group settings and has been used with respondents 18 years and older. Participants indicate their responses to each of the 21 items in the blank space provided after each item. They indicate their responses on a Likert scale anchored at the extremes with never (1) and always (6). The Exercise Dependence Scale requires approximately 5 minutes to complete.

form.longName: PhenX PX650301 - Child Eating Behavior Questionnaire Cebq
form.preferredDefinition: The Child Eating Behavior Questionnaire (CEBQ) is a 35-item parent-report questionnaire assessing eating style in children. Eating style is assessed on eight scales: food responsiveness (4 items), enjoyment of food (4 items), emotional overeating (4 items), desire to drink (3 items), satiety responsiveness (5 items), slowness in eating (4 items), and emotional undereating (4 items), and fussiness (7 items). Informants rate the frequency of their child's behaviors and experiences on a 5-point scale: 1 = never, 2 = rarely, 3 = sometimes, 4 = often, 5 = always.

question.questionText: Child Eating Behavior Questionnaire (CEBQ). Please read the following statements and choose the box most appropriate to your child's eating behavior. (instructions_650301)
My child loves food (EF) (eatingscale_child_loves_food)
My child eats more when worried (EOE) (eatingscale_child_eats_more_whenworried)
My child has a big appetite (SR*) (eatingscale_child_big_appetite)
My child finishes his/her meal quickly (SE*) (eatingscale_child_finishes_meal_quickly)
My child is interested in food (EF) (eatingscale_child_interested_in_food)
My child is always asking for a drink (DD) (eatingscale_child_alwaysasking_for_drink)
My child refuses new foods at first (FF) (eatingscale_child_refuses_new_food)
My child eats slowly (SE) (eatingscale_child_eats_slowly)
My child eats less when angry (EUE) (eatingscale_child_eats_less_whenangry)
My child enjoys tasting new foods (FF*) (eatingscale_child_enjoys_tasting_newfood)
My child eats less when s/he is tired (EUE) (eatingscale_child_eats_less_whentired)
My child is always asking for food (FR) (eatingscale_child_alwaysasking_for_food)
My child eats more when annoyed (EOE) (eatingscale_child_eats_more_whenannoyed)
If allowed to, my child would eat too much (FR) (eatingscale_child_allowed_eat_toomuch)
My child eats more when anxious (EOE) (eatingscale_child_eats_more_whenanxious)
My child enjoys a wide variety of foods (FF*) (eatingscale_child_enjoys_wide_variety)
My child leaves food on his/her plate at the end of a meal (SR) (eatingscale_child_leaves_food_onplate)
My child takes more than 30 minutes to finish a meal (SE) (eatingscale_child_morethan_30minute_mealtime)
Given the choice, my child would eat most of the time (FR) (eatingscale_child_allowed_eat_mostoftime)
My child looks forward to mealtimes (EF) (eatingscale_child_looksforward_tomeal)
My child gets full before his/her meal is finished (SR) (eatingscale_child_getsfull_before_mealfinished)
My child enjoys eating (EF) (eatingscale_child_enjoys_eating)
My child eats more when s/he is happy (EUE) (eatingscale_child_eats_more_whenhappy)
My child is difficult to please with meals (FF) (eatingscale_child_difficult_toplease_meals)
My child eats less when upset (EUE) (eatingscale_child_eats_less_whenupset)
My child gets full up easily (SR) (eatingscale_child_getsfull_up_easily)
My child eats more when s/he has nothing else to do (EOE) (eatingscale_child_eats_more_whenbored)
Even if my child is full up s/he finds room to eat his/her favorite food (FR) (eatingscale_child_eats_more_favoritefood)
If given the chance, my child would drink continuously throughout the day (DD) (eatingscale_child_drink_continuously)
My child cannot eat a meal if s/he has had a snack just before (SR) (eatingscale_child_cannoteat_meal_aftersnack)
If given the chance, my child would always be having a drink (DD) (eatingscale_child_always_having_drink)
My child is interested in tasting food s/he hasn't tasted before (FF) (eatingscale_child_interested_tasting_newfood)
My child decides that s/he doesn't like a food, even without tasting it (FF) (eatingscale_child_doesntlike_food_withouttasting)
If given the chance, my child would always have food in his/her mouth (FR) (eatingscale_child_alwayshave_food_inmouth)
My child eats more and more slowly during the course of a meal (SE) (eatingscale_child_always_havefood_inmouth)

SCORING OF THE CEBQ(Never = 1, Rarely = 2, Sometimes = 3, Often = 4, Always = 5) Food responsiveness = mean of items labelled FR Emotional overeating = mean of items labelled EOE Enjoyment of food = mean of items labelled EF Desire to drink = mean of items labelled DD Satiety responsiveness = mean of items labelled SR Slowness in eating = mean of items labelled SE Emotional undereating = mean of items labelled EUE Food fussiness = mean of items labelled FF*Reversed items (scoring_650301)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Child Eating Behavior Questionnaire (CEBQ) is a 35-item parent-report questionnaire assessing eating style in children. Eating style is assessed on eight scales: food responsiveness (4 items), enjoyment of food (4 items), emotional overeating (4 items), desire to drink (3 items), satiety responsiveness (5 items), slowness in eating (4 items), and emotional undereating (4 items), and fussiness (7 items). Informants rate the frequency of their child's behaviors and experiences on a 5-point scale: 1 = never, 2 = rarely, 3 = sometimes, 4 = often, 5 = always.

form.longName: PhenX PX650501 - Yalebrowncornell Eating Disorder Scale Ybceds
form.preferredDefinition: The Yale-Brown-Cornell Eating Disorder Scale (YBC-EDS) is an interviewer-administered scale that includes a comprehensive checklist of 21 preoccupations and 44 rituals involving food, eating, weight, shape and appearance, clothing, hoarding food, and exercise. This total number of possible symptoms is organized into 16 symptom categories based on thematic concerns. The checklist applies to two periods: current and worst. After completing the preoccupations checklist, the rater asks each preoccupation and ritual follow-up question for current (past month) then worst. Follow-up questions are scored from 0 to 4.

question.questionText: Check all that apply: Categorizes all food into good" or "bad"" (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_categorize_food)
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the fat content of food (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_fat_content)
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the caloric content of food (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_caloric_content)
Check all that apply: Thinks excessively about the sugar content of food (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_sugar_content)
Check all that apply: Fears that eating a certain type of food will lead to immediate body changes, e.g. eating fat will deposit fat to hips (ocd_eatingtraits_foodpreoccupations_body_changes)
Check all that apply: Fear of eating from a full plate of food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_full_plate)
Check all that apply: Fear of eating all of the food that is on a plate of food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_eating_allfood)
Check all that apply: Fear of consuming fluids (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_consuming_fluids)
Check all that apply: Fear of not being able to consume fluids (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_notconsuming_fluids)
Check all that apply: Fear of being unable to eat (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_unable_toeat)
Check all that apply: Fear of being unable to stop eating (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_unable_tostop)

Check all that apply: Fear of eating in front of other people (note: this can reflect fear that others will regard the subjects' eating negatively because they are so fat or this can also involve magical thinking such as absorbing calories that other people eat) (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingpreoccupations_infront_others)
Check all that apply: Fear of being fat or overweight (ocd_eatingtraits_weightpreoccupations_fear_beingfat)
Check all that apply: Fear of weighing outside of a narrow range or preoccupation with a specific weight (ocd_eatingtraits_weightpreoccupations_fear_others)
Check all that apply: Excessive concern with a specific body part or aspect of appearance (ocd_eatingtraits_shapepreoccupations_excessive_concern)
Check all that apply: Fear of others thinking she is fat (ocd_eatingtraits_shapepreoccupations_fear_others)

Check all that apply: Excessive concern with size of clothing, e.g. would not buy clothing that was not a size 3 even if it fit and looked good (ocd_eatingtraits_clothingpreoccupations_excessive_concern)
Check all that apply: Fear of wearing certain types of clothing, e.g. fear of wearing underwear (ocd_eatingtraits_clothingpreoccupations_typesof_clothing)
Check all that apply: Fear of wearing either tight or loose fitting clothing (ocd_eatingtraits_clothingpreoccupations_tight_clothing)
Check all that apply: Hoarding food preoccupations (ocd_eatingtraits_hoarding_food_preoccupations)
Check all that apply: Exercise preoccupations (ocd_eatingtraits_exercise_preoccupations)
Check all that apply: Other preoccupations (ocd_eatingtraits_other_preoccupations)
Check all that apply: Need to consume food at a specific rate, e.g. can take a bite only every 2 minutes (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_specific_rate)
Check all that apply: Need to chew each mouthful of food a specific number of times (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_chew_number)
Check all that apply: Need to cut each piece of food into a specific size (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_cut_size)
Check all that apply: Need to consume only certain colors or types of foods (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_color_food)
Check all that apply: Need to avoid certain types of foods, e.g. fats, meats (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_avoid_types)
Check all that apply: Need to consume each food type completely and in a specific order, e.g. must eat all green beans before potatoes can be eaten (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_consumeorder_food)
Check all that apply: Need to consume fluids in a certain way or amount, e.g. need to drink 2 glasses of water before eating any meal (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_consumeorder_fluids)
Check all that apply: Need to eat meals by oneself (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_eat_alone)
Check all that apply: Need to leave food on the plate when done eating, cannot consume all food on plate (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_leave_food)
Check all that apply: Need to manipulate or stir food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_manipulate_food)
Check all that apply: Need to fill glass or plate only partially, cannot fill glass or plate fully (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_fill_partially)
Check all that apply: Need to have the table set in a specific way before she can eat (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_table_set)
Check all that apply: Need to wipe mouth with napkin a fixed number of times after each bite of food (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_napkin_number)
Check all that apply: Food cannot touch lips (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_food_nolips)
Check all that apply: No part of the body can touch the table or plate (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_nobody_touch)
Check all that apply: Need for absolute constancy of food expected, e.g. an orange could not be substituted if an apple was expected (ocd_eatingtraits_eatingrituals_absolute_constancy)
Check all that apply: Need to compute caloric content of all foods eaten (ocd_eatingtraits_foodrituals_compute_calories)
Check all that apply: Need to compute fat content of all foods eaten (ocd_eatingtraits_foodrituals_fat_content)
Check all that apply: Need to cook for others (ocd_eatingtraits_foodrituals_cook_forothers)
Check all that apply: Need to begin each binge with a certain type of food or with food of a certain color (ocd_eatingtraits_bingeingrituals_starting_typecolor)
Check all that apply: Need to eat only a certain type(s) of food (ocd_eatingtraits_bingeingrituals_certain_type)
Check all that apply: Need to eat all food that is present (can leave no food uneaten no matter what it is) (ocd_eatingtraits_bingeingrituals_eat_allfood)
Check all that apply: Need to purge in a specific way or position, e.g. must use 2 fingers (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_way)
Check all that apply: Need to purge a specific minimum amount (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_minimumamount)
Check all that apply: Need to purge a specific amount of time after eating (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_time)
Check all that apply: Need to use a specific number of laxatives (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_laxatives)
Check all that apply: Need to purge in a specific place (ocd_eatingtraits_purgeingrituals_specific_place)
Check all that apply: Need to have thighs not touch while sitting or standing (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_thighs_nottouching)
Check all that apply: Need to continually check that wrist can be spanned with fingers (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_thin_wrists)
Check all that apply: Need to feel hip bones repeatedly (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_feel_hips)
Check all that apply: Need to see a specific bone, e.g. wrist (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_see_specificbone)
Check all that apply: Ritualized bathroom habits, e.g. pushing on lower stomach when urinating or defecating (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_ritualized_bathroomhabits)
Check all that apply: Need to overdress to force sweating (ocd_eatingtraits_somaticrituals_overdress_sweating)
Check all that apply: Need to repeatedly weigh oneself or to repeatedly check one's weight (ocd_eatingtraits_weightrituals_repeated_weighing)
Check all that apply: Need to weigh oneself only in ritualize ways, e.g. nude, at 8 AM, after meals or defecating (ocd_eatingtraits_weightrituals_ritualized_weighing)
Check all that apply: Need to exercise after meals (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_after_meals)
Check all that apply: Need to exercise in a specific way and/or at a specific time, e.g. can only do situps at 7 AM and run at 4 PM (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_specific_waytime)

Check all that apply: Ritualized exercise pattern, e.g. must do 50 situps, if interrupted while doing the 49th must begin over again and do all 50. (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_ritualized_pattern)
Check all that apply: Need to be moving at all times, cannot sit still, paces, fidgets (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_moving_alltimes)
Check all that apply: Need to shiver to expend calories rather than putting on additional clothing (ocd_eatingtraits_exerciserituals_shiver_calories)
Check all that apply: Hoarding food in a ritualized way. (ocd_eatingtraits_hoardingrituals_ritualized_way)
Check all that apply: Collecting and saving recipes, pictures of food, articles on food (ocd_eatingtraits_hoardingrituals_collecting_picturesrecipes)
Check all that apply: Lists of body weight (ocd_eatingtraits_excessivelistmaking_lists_bodyweight)
Check all that apply: Lists of caloric intake (ocd_eatingtraits_excessivelistmaking_caloric_intake)
Check all that apply: Other (ocd_eatingtraits_excessivelistmaking_other)

question.questionText: How much of an effort do you make to resist the preoccupations? How often do you try to disregard or turn your attention away from these thoughts as they enter your mind? [Only rate effort made to resist, not success or failure in actually controlling the preoccupations. Note that this item does not directly measure the severity of the intrusive thoughts rather it rates a manifestation of health, i.e., the effort the patient makes to counteract the preoccupations by means other than avoidance or the performance of rituals. question.questionText: How much of an effort do you make to resist performing the rituals? [Only rate effort made to resist, not success or failure in actually controlling the rituals. Thus, the more the patient tried to resist, the less impaired is this aspect of her/his functioning. If the rituals are minimal, the patient may not feel the need to resist them. protocol.preferredDefinition: The Yale-Brown-Cornell Eating Disorder Scale (YBC-EDS) is an interviewer-administered scale that includes a comprehensive checklist of 21 preoccupations and 44 rituals involving food, eating, weight, shape and appearance, clothing, hoarding food, and exercise. This total number of possible symptoms is organized into 16 symptom categories based on thematic concerns. The checklist applies to two periods: current and worst. After completing the preoccupations checklist, the rater asks each preoccupation and ritual follow-up question for current (past month) then worst. Follow-up questions are scored from 0 to 4.

form.longName: PhenX PX650601 - Positive And Negative Perfectionism Scale
form.preferredDefinition: The Positive and Negative Perfectionism Scale is a 40-item self-report inventory to assess the levels of positive and negative perfectionism. Respondents are asked to complete the questionnaire using a 5-point response format, indicating for each item either "strongly agree" (scored 5), "agree" (scored 4), "don't know" (scored 3), "disagree" (scored 2), or "strongly disagree" (scored 1). Scores for positive perfectionism and negative perfectionism, each with 20 questions, can range from 20 to 100, with higher values indicating greater positive and negative perfectionism, respectively.

headerInstruction.text: Positive and Negative Perfectionism Scale : Please choose the appropriate answer which applies best to each of the following statements. Please answer each statement.5= Strongly Agree4= Agree3= Don't know2= Disagree1= Strongly DisagreeAll repl..TRUNCATED

question.questionText: 1. When I start something I feel anxious that I might fail. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_anxiety_failure)
2. My family and friends are proud of me when I do really well. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_proud_dowell)
3. I take pride in being meticulous when doing things. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_pride_meticulous)
4. I set impossibly high standards for myself. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_impossible_highstandards)
5. I try to avoid the disapproval of others at all costs. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_avoid_disapproval)
6. I like the acclaim I get for an outstanding performance. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_praise_performance)
7. When I am doing something I cannot relax until it's perfect. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_relax_whenperfect)
8. It feels as though my best is never good enough for other people. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_best_notgoodenough)
9. Producing a perfect performance is a reward in its own right. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_perfectperformance_rewarding)
10. The problem of success is that I must work even harder. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_problemof_success)
11. If I make a mistake I feel that the whole thing is ruined. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_mistake_whole_ruined)
12. I feel dissatisfied with myself unless I am working towards a higher standard all the time. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_dissatisfied_higher_standard)
13. I know the kind of person I ought or want to be, but feel I always fall short of this. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_fallshort_want_tobe)
14. Other people respect me for my achievements. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_others_respect_achievements)
15. As a child however well I did, it never seemed good enough to please my parents. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_never_goodenough)
16. I think everyone loves a winner. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_everyone_winner)
17. Other people expect nothing less than perfection of me. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_others_nothingless_perfection)
18. When I'm competing against others, I'm motivated by wanting to be the best. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_competition_motivatedby)
19. I feel good when pushing out the limits. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_feelgood_push_limits)
20. When I achieve my goals I feel dissatisfied. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_dissatisfied_achieve_goals)
21. My high standards are admired by others. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_highstandards_admired_others)
22. If I fail people, I fear they will cease to respect or care for me. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_failure_cease_respect)
23. I like to please other people by being successful. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_pleaseothers_bysuccess)
24. I gain great approval from others by the quality of my accomplishments. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_gainapproval_byaccomplishments)
25. My successes spur me on to greater achievements. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_successleadto_achievements)
26. I feel guilty or ashamed if I do less than perfectly. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_feelguilty_lessperfect)
27. No matter how well I do I never feel satisfied with my performance. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_never_satisfied_withperformance)
28. I believe that rigorous practice makes for perfection. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_practice_makes_perfection)
29. I enjoy the glory gained by successes. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_glory_from_success)
30. I gain deep satisfaction when I have perfected something. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_satisfaction_fromperfection)
31. I feel I have to be perfect to gain people's approval. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_beperfect_gainapproval)
32. My parents encouraged me to excel. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_parents_encouragement)
33. I worry what others think if I make mistakes. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_worry_others)
34. I get fulfillment from totally dedicating myself to a task. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_fullfillment_fromdedication)
35. I like it when others recognize that what I do requires great skill and effort to perfect. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_others_recognize_requiredskills)
36. The better I do, the better I am expected to do by others. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_betterperformance_byothers)
37. I enjoy working towards greater levels of precision and accuracy. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_enjoy_greaterlevels_precisionaccuracy)
38. I would rather not start something than risk doing it less than perfectly. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_notstartif_lessthanperfect)
39. When I do things I feel others will judge critically the standard of my work. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_judged_critically)
40. I like the challenge of setting very high standards for myself. (perfectionismscale_adolescentadult_challenge_highstandards)

Scoring: The Positive and Negative Perfectionism Scale includes two subscales:Positive perfectionism items 2, 3, 6, 9, 14, 16, 18, 19, 21, 23, 24, 25, 28, 29, 30, 32, 34, 35, 37, 40.Negative perfectionism items 1, 4, 5, 7, 8, 10, 11, 12, 13, 15, 17, 20, 22, 26, 27, 31, 33, 36, 38, 39.Item responses are summed to give individual subscale scores that can range from 20 to 100. Higher values indicate greater positive and negative perfectionism. (scoring_650601)

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Positive and Negative Perfectionism Scale is a 40-item self-report inventory to assess the levels of positive and negative perfectionism. Respondents are asked to complete the questionnaire using a 5-point response format, indicating for each item either "strongly agree" (scored 5), "agree" (scored 4), "don't know" (scored 3), "disagree" (scored 2), or "strongly disagree" (scored 1). Scores for positive perfectionism and negative perfectionism, each with 20 questions, can range from 20 to 100, with higher values indicating greater positive and negative perfectionism, respectively.

form.longName: PhenX PX650701 - Intolerance Of Uncertainty Scale Ius
form.preferredDefinition: The Intolerance of Uncertainty Scale (IUS) includes 27 items relating to the idea that uncertainty is unacceptable, reflects badly on a person, and leads to frustration, stress, and the inability to take action. Participants rate items on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = "not at all characteristic of me" to 5 = "entirely characteristic of me." The protocol includes scoring instructions.

question.questionText: Scoring Instructions The IUS may be used as a unifactorial or a bifactorial assessment tool. To score the IUS as a unifactorial tool, add up the responses for each of the items. As a bifactorial tool, the IUS is used to assess the following two factors:Factor 1: Uncertainty has negative behavioural and selfreferent implications Factor 2: Uncertainty is unfair and spoils everythingTo score Factor 1, add up the responses for items 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 20, 22, 23, 24, and 25To score Factor 2, add up the responses for items 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 18, 19, 21, 26, and 27Scoring Instructions The IUS may be used as a unifactorial or a bifactorial assessment tool. To score the IUS as a unifactorial tool, add up the responses for each of the items. As a bifactorial tool, the IUS is used to assess the following two factors:Factor 1: Uncertainty has negative behavioural and selfreferent implications Factor 2: Uncertainty is unfair and spoils everythingTo score Factor 1, add up the responses for items 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 20, 22, 23, 24, and 25To score Factor 2, add up the responses for items 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 10, 11, 18, 19, 21, 26, and 27 (scoring_650701)

Participants rate items on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = "not at all characteristic of me" to 5 = "entirely characteristic of me." The protocol includes scoring instructions.

form.longName: PhenX PX651201 - Questionnaire Of Eating And Weight Patterns Adult
form.preferredDefinition: The Questionnaire of Eating and Weight Patterns-5 (QEWP-5) has been updated to accommodate binge-eating disorder (BED) and bulimia nervosa criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Eating Disorders. It includes 26 items that screen respondents for BED. The questionnaire can be used to differentiate BED from bulimia nervosa and to document the presence of "subjective binge" episodes (i.e., episodes of loss-of-control eating that are not characterized by the intake of an objectively large amount of food). The QEWP-5 also includes body silhouettes and respondents choose those that most resemble the body builds of their biological father and mother at their heaviest. These silhouettes are scored on a 1-9 scale. Scoring instructions are included.

Scoring: DECISION RULES FOR SCREENING FOR POSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BINGE EATING DISORDER(BED) USING THE QUESTIONNAIRE ON EATING AND WEIGHT PATTERNS 5(FOR RATER'S USE ONLYPOSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BED.QUESTION NUMBERRESPONSE*8 AND 9 1 (BINGE EATING)*10 2, 3, 4, 5, OR 6 (AT LEAST 1 EPISODE PER WEEK FOR THREE MONTHS)*11 a through e 3 OR MORE ITEMS MARKED "YES" (AT LEAST 3 ASSOCIATED SYMPTOMS DURING BINGE EATING EPISODES)* 13 4 0R 5 (MARKED DISTRESS REGARDING BINGE EATING)POSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BED REQUIRES ALL OF THE ABOVE ALONG WITH THE ABSENCE OF INAPPROPRIATE COMPENSATORY BEHAVIORS AS SEEN IN BULIMIA NERVOSA, AS DEFINED BELOW.POSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BULIMIA NERVOSA.QUESTION NUMBERRESPONSE*8 AND 9 1 (BINGE EATING)*10 2, 3, 4, 5, OR 6 (AT LEAST 1 EPISODE PER WEEK FOR THREE MONTHS)*14,15,16,17,18, OR 19 ANY RESPONSE 2, 3, 4, 5, OR 6 (INAPPROPRIATE COMPENSATORY BEHAVIOR AT LEAST 1 TIME PER WEEK FOR THREE MONTHS)*13 4 0R 5 (MARKED DISTRESS REGARDING BINGE EATING)QUESTIONS FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES ONLY (NOT TO BE USED FOR DIAGNOSIS OF BED OR BULIMIA NERVOSA) QUESTION NUMBERRESPONSE*12 a through d EXAMINER'S JUDGMENT THAT AMOUNT OF FOOD DESCRIBED IS UNUSUALLY LARGE GIVEN CIRCUMSTANCES (I.E., TIME OF DAY, HOURS SINCE PREVIOUS MEAL)Yes _____ NO____ UNSURE*21 1 (SUBJECTIVE BULIMIC EPISODE/LOSS OF CONTROL EATING)*24 a through d EXAMINER'S JUDGMENT THAT AMOUNT OF FOOD DESCRIBED IS UNUSUALLY LARGE GIVEN CIRCUMSTANCES (I.E., TIME OF DAY, HOURS SINCE PREVIOUS MEAL) Yes _____ NO____ UNSURE*26 SILHOUETTES MAY BE USED TO ESTIMATE PARENTAL HISTORY OF OBESITY (scoring_651201)

protocol.longName: Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns - Adult
protocol.preferredDefinition: The Questionnaire of Eating and Weight Patterns-5 (QEWP-5) has been updated to accommodate binge-eating disorder (BED) and bulimia nervosa criteria in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Eating Disorders. It includes 26 items that screen respondents for BED. The questionnaire can be used to differentiate BED from bulimia nervosa and to document the presence of "subjective binge" episodes (i.e., episodes of loss-of-control eating that are not characterized by the intake of an objectively large amount of food). The QEWP-5 also includes body silhouettes and respondents choose those that most resemble the body builds of their biological father and mother at their heaviest. These silhouettes are scored on a 1-9 scale. Scoring instructions are included.

form.longName: PhenX PX651202 - Questionnaire Of Eating And Weight Patterns Child
form.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes the child/adolescent version of the Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns (QEWP-C-5) updated for the diagnostic changes in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Ed. (DSM-5). The questionnaire is an updated version of the Questionnaire of Eating and Weight Pattern for Adolescents (QEWP-A). The QEWP-C-5 is a 32-item self-report scale that was designed to screen for a possible diagnosis of binge-eating disorder. It also can be used to screen for the presence of bulimia nervosa. Scoring instructions are included. The QEWP-C-5 also includes body silhouettes, and respondents choose those that most resemble the body builds of their biological father and mother at their heaviest. These silhouettes are scored on a 1-9 scale. These items provide information about the presence of parental obesity, but are not included in scoring.

question.questionText: 1. During the past three months, did you ever eat what most people, like your friends, would think was a REALLY BIG amount of food? (eatingweightpatterns_child_bigamount)

3. When you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food, did you ever feel you could not stop eating or control what or how much you were eating? (eatingweightpatterns_child_bigamount_losecontrol)

When you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt like you could not control your eating, did you usually: (q5_651202)
5a. Eat very fast? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_rapidly)
5b. Eat until your stomach hurt or you felt sick to your stomach? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_pain)
5c. Eat REALLY BIG amounts of food even when you were not hungry? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_nothungry)
5d. Eat by yourself because you did not want anyone to see how much you ate? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_alone)

6a. Think about a usual time when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt you could not control your eating: What time of day did the episode start? (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_time)

Be specific include brand names where possible, and amounts or portion sizes as best you can estimate. (eatingweightpatterns_child_losecontrol_list)

7. During the past three months, how bad did you feel when you ate a REALLY BIG amount of food and felt your eating was out of control? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_feelbad)

IF YES: How often, in general, did you do that? (eatingweightpatterns_child_threemonths_losecontrol_vomityes)

Decision Rules for Screening for Possible Diagnosis of Binge Eating Disorder (BED) Using the Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns5 for Children.Possible Diagnosis of BED1) Response of 1 on Question 12) Response of 1 on Question 23) Response of 1 on Question 3 (binge eating)) Response of 2, 3, 4, 5, OR 6 on Question 4 (at least 1 binge episode per week for 3 months) 5) 3 OR MORE ITEMS MARKED "YES" (i.e. 1) on Questions 5ae (at least associated symptoms during binge eating episodes)6) Response of 4 or 5 on Question 7 (marked distress regarding binge eating)POSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BED REQUIRES ALL OF THE ABOVE SIX (6) ITEMS, ALONG WITH THE ABSENCE OF INAPPROPRIATE COMPENSATORY BEHAVIORS AS SEEN IN BULIMIA NERVOSA, AS DEFINED FURTHER BELOW.POSSIBLE DIAGNOSIS OF BULIMIA NERVOSA REQUIRES ALL OF THE BELOW FOUR (4) ITEMS1) Response of 1 on Question 12) Response of 1 on Question 23) Response of 1 on Question 3 (binge eating)4) Response of 2, 3, 4, 5, OR 6 on Question 4 (at least binge 1 episode per week for 3 months)5) ANY Response of 2, 3, 4, 5 OR 6 on Questions 8, 10, 12, 13, 14, or 16 (inappropriate compensatory behavior at least 1 time per week for 3 months)6) Response of 3 or 4 on Question 17 (overvaluation of weight/shape). protocol.longName: Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns - Child
protocol.preferredDefinition: This protocol includes the child/adolescent version of the Questionnaire on Eating and Weight Patterns (QEWP-C-5) updated for the diagnostic changes in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, 5th Ed. (DSM-5). The questionnaire is an updated version of the Questionnaire of Eating and Weight Pattern for Adolescents (QEWP-A). The QEWP-C-5 is a 32-item self-report scale that was designed to screen for a possible diagnosis of binge-eating disorder. It also can be used to screen for the presence of bulimia nervosa. Scoring instructions are included. The QEWP-C-5 also includes body silhouettes, and respondents choose those that most resemble the body builds of their biological father and mother at their heaviest. These silhouettes are scored on a 1-9 scale. These items provide information about the presence of parental obesity, but are not included in scoring.
